isis.stitle: TSI 05-12-34 - Systematic Method to Diagnose an Engine Overheat Condition

subjectgroup.subject: Systematic Method to Diagnose an Engine Overheat Condition

geninfo.para: It is important to diagnose the root cause for engine overheating before replacing parts.
The accompanying worksheet will assist in determining the course of action to diagnose and remedy engine overheating.

svcproc.title: Service procedure

warning.para: To avoid property damage, personal injury, or death, park the vehicle on a flat level surface, set the parking brake, turn the engine off, and chock the wheels.

svcproc.para: What is the customer reporting coolant temperature to be? How long does the coolant remain at the reported temperature?
Did the surge tank boil over? Yes / No (If yes test the pressure cap)
What is the ambient temperature when coolant runs hot?
Is the coolant in the surge tank between the ADD and FULL lines? Yes / No
What is the freeze protection? (Straight antifreeze is a poor coolant.)
When does the overheat condition occur? ( Circle) On a long hill, Stop and go driving, On highway, Stationary
Does the engine have low coolant level, derate, high coolant temperature, warning, or shutdown fault codes? (List Codes)
What does engine event history show? Code: ECM hours: Current ECM hours:
Is the fan engaging? Yes / No At what coolant temperature? At what ambient air temperature at the fan clutch? If yes measure the fan speed at high idle with a phototach. Fan RPM:
Note: Refer to TSI-00-12-05: Fan speed should be at least 80% of input speed when fully engaged. (Viscous fan clutch only)
Is the radiator and charge air cooler clear of obstructions? Yes/No
If the radiator is dirty, clean the radiator following the procedure found in TSI-02-12-01 or TSI-98-12-18.
Has the radiator been inspected for solder bloom or other plugging? Yes/No Any action taken?
With an EZ-Tech measure the coolant temperature?
What components have been changed in an attempt to correct the overheat condition?
Note: If the fan drive was replaced, what is the Part Number?

With the engine up to operating temperature, measure (using a heat gun) the inlet radiator tank and the outlet radiator tank temperatures to determine the coolant temperature drop across the radiator. Inlet Temperature: Outlet Temperature: Cluster Gauge Temperature:
If vehicle is equipped with an Allison transmission, record the oil pan temperature. Oil Temperature:
If the vehicle is equipped with an Allison transmission, does it have an additional cooler? Yes/No If Yes, where is it mounted and how is it plumbed into the transmission and radiator cooler?
What does the transmission fluid look and smell like?
Are the re-circulation seals in place around the radiator? Yes/No

Note: Normal operating temperature for International VT 365, T 444E, DT 466E, 530E and 570E engines is between 190°F and 212°F. Intermittent operation up to 230°F is not unusual in some vocations and environments. Refer vehicle owners to the Engine Operation and Maintenance Manual.
Note: Illumination of the oil/water light and fault code 321 (warning) or fault code 322 (shutdown) are considered an Overheat condition.
